DIV1.P: THE FAMILY PARTY; A COMIC PIECE, IN TWO ACTS, AS ACTED AT THE THEATRE ROYAL, HAYMARKET.
LONDON: Printed for J. DEBRETT, opposite Burlington House, Piccadilly. M.DCC.LXXXIX. [Price One Shilling.]

DIV1.HEAD: PROLOGUE BY THE AUTHOR. Spoken by Mr. J. BANNISTER.
DIV1.L: STRANGE there's such magic virtue in a name,
Which deals out censure, or dispenses fame!
And that a taking title tends to raise
Dress—Snuff—Quack Med'cines—Pamphlets—Peers and Plays!
Brick-dust call'd—Dentifrice, will current pass;
And mutton-suet for—Pomade de Grasse!
Some cry, "Corruption undermines a Nation,"
Start at a bribe, but touch a—compensation.
Poor Lady Muzzy can't a dram endure;
Quite faints at brandy, but can sip—Liqueur.
Thus, a mere name can gild a nauseous pill,
Enslave our Reason, and direct our Will!
Since wide extends this empire of caprice,
Our Author, surely, has miscall'd his Piece!
"The FAMILY PARTY!" cries Sir Squander Dash,
"Oh, 'tis some wretched matrimonial hash,
"Where two poor Devils whine and mope together,
"Loll—pick their teeth—look glum—and blame the "weather."
As Lady Listless with her sposo sits,
Stares full at nothing—nods, and starts by fits:
While her gay Lord reclin'd on sofa, lies!
Twirls round his watch-key—yawns and rubs his eyes.
Descending from the Great—suppose we pop
Into the snug back-parlour thro' the shop,
Where a faint twilight o'er the dingy room,
Peeps from the dirty pane's congenial gloom;
Old Grub, with warm plaid gown and velvet cap,
With Dearee takes his after-dinner nap:
Who joins in unison the social doze,
And snores responsive to his vocal nose!
In bounces Miss from school—slap goes the door—
Shook from the peg and rumpled on the floor,
Down drops Papa's best wig—so spruce, so neat!
Fresh oil'd and powder'd for—churchwarden's seat!
Papa growls, but Mamma attends all glee,
While Miss to crack'd guittar, squalls "Chere amie."
Pleas'd, cries Mamma, "What think ye, if to-day
"We take our Betsy with us to the Play?
"The bill of fare bespeaks a welcome hearty,
"Snug too, and sociable—The FAMILY PARTY."
"The FAMILY PARTY! hold your tongue," says he,
"The very name, egad's, enough for me!
"I'm for what's new—no need abroad to roam
"For that dull Farce we've play'd so long at home."
Thus, all say, Dullness, with her leaden seal,
Marks for her own, each Party en famille:
But if sage Critics condescend to share
A Poet's treat, none thinks of sumptuous fare;
Bring Candour with you, a most welcome guest,
To two slight dishes, by no French cook drest!
With those, our Friends we gratefully invite
To our domestic Party here to-Night.

DIV1.HEAD: ADVERTISEMENT.
DIV1.P: PREFACES have been generally considered as Prologues to the Reader; and various have been the methods made use of in them, to depre∣cate the censure, and conciliate the favour of the Public. These have been long since, as Chaucer says, "bolted to the bran;" nor would the Author of this dramatic trifle have adopted the practice on the present occasion, did it not give him an oppor∣tunity of acknowledging, that the very flattering reception it obtained on the Stage, was greatly to be ascribed to the inimitable performance of Mr. J. BANNISTER.

DIV1.HEAD: DRAMATIS PERSONAE.
DIV1.P: SCENE — Bath.

DIV1.HEAD: NEW PUBLICATIONS PRINTED FOR J. DEBRETT.
DIV1.P: MARY, QUEEN of SCOTS, a Tragedy, as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. By the Hon. JOHN ST. JOHN. Third Edition. Price 1s. 6d.
FALSE APPEARANCES, a Comedy, altered from the French, and performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. By the Right Hon. General CONWAY. Price 1s. 6d.
HALF AN HOUR AFTER SUPPER, an Interlude, as performed at the Theatre Royal, Hay Market. Price 1s.
The FARM HOUSE, a Comedy, as altered by J. P. KEM∣BLE, and performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. Second Edition. Price 1s.
The HEIRESS, a Comedy. By Lieut. General BUR∣GOYNE. As performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. The Seventh Edition. Price 1s. 6d.
L'ECOLE DU SCANDALE, ou Les Moeurs du Jour, Co∣medie. Par M. SHERIDAN. Traduite en François par M. BUNEL DE LILLE, Avocat au Parlement de Paris. Price 3s. 6d.
RICHARD COEUR DE LION, from the French of Mon∣sieur SEDAINE, as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. The Second Edition. Price 1s.
The DISTRESSED BARONET, a Farce, in Two Acts, as performed at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane. Second Edition. Price 1s.

A NARRATIVE of the EXPEDITION to BOTANY BAY; with an Account of New South Wales, its Inhabitants, Productions, &c. to which is subjoined, a List of the Civil and Military Establishment at Port Jackson. By Captain WATKIN TENCH, of the Marines. Third Edition. Price 3s. 6d. sewed.

The LIFE of FREDERICK THE SECOND, King of Prussia: To which are added, Observations, authentic Docu∣ment, and a Variety of interesting Anecdotes: Translated from the French, of Professor LAVAUX. In Two large Vo∣lumes. Price 14s. in Boards. We have no hesitation in say∣ing, that this is by far the best Life of Frederick in English, or indeed that we have seen. Appendix to Critical Review, vol. 67.
QUERIES concerning the CONDUCT which ENGLAND should follow in Foreign Politics, in the present State of Europe. By Sir JOHN DALRYMPLE, Bart. one of the Barons of Exchequer in Scotland. Price 2s. 6d.

REMARKS on the PRUSSIAN TREATY: To which is added, an authentic Copy of the Treaty of Defensive Alli∣ance between his Majesty the King of Great Britain and the King of Prussia; signed at Berlin, August 13, 1788. Price 1s. 6d.

OBSERVATIONS on the LAND REVENUE of the CROWN, containing the Origin and Sources of the Land Re∣venue of England; various Accessions to and Alienations of the Crown Lands. Present State of the Land Revenue. Management of the Land Revenue. Various Measures and Projects concerning the Land Revenue; with an Appendix containing several interesting Papers on the Crown Lands. By the Hon. JOHN ST. JOHN. Price 10s. 6d. in Boards.

The REPORT from the SELECT COMMITTEE, to whom it was referred to examine and state the several Accounts, and other Papers presented to the House of Commons, rela∣ting to the Public Income and Expenditure: And also, to re∣port to the House what may be expected to be the Annual Amount of the said Income and Expenditure in future. March 21, 1786. Price 3s.

{inverted ⁂} This important Report contains an authentic State∣ment of every Part of the British Revenue; with Documents and Vouchers for every Department and Office; and includes the Appendix complete.

In the Press and speedily will be published, elegantly prin∣ted in One Volume, Quarto, illustrated with a great Variety of Plates of Non-descript Animals, Birds, Serpents, Lizards, curious Cones of Trees, &c. &c. and other Natural Produc∣tions of New South Wales, copied from Nature by Miss Stone, and engraved by the best Artists, of a JOURNAL of a VOY∣AGE to BOTANY BAY, in NEW SOUTH WALES. With a full and accurate Account of His Majesty's Settlement at that Place, PORT JACKSON, and NORFOLK ISLAND; a Description of the Natives, a correct Diary of the Weather, Latitudes and Longitudes, &c. &c. By JOHN WHITE, Esq. Surgeon General to His Majesty's Forces, and to the Settle∣ment in New South Wales.

{inverted ⁂} Specimens, in fine Preservation, of the Subjects in Natural History, transmitted by Mr. White, may be seen at J. Debrett's, who will thankfully receive the Names of such Noblemen and Gentlemen, who may be pleased to patronize Mr. White's Journal.

SP.SPEAKER: Young Spriggins

Q.L: "YE Gods! annihilate but time and space
"A pretty reasonable request for two lovers!"

SP.P: Egad! not so unreasonable neither—for a man may travel in England as fast as a balloon, if he will but fill the post-boy with the inflammable gas of the brandy bottle, and readily empty his pocket of his BALLAST.
Ha! if I can believe my eyes—my old Eton friend, Jack Spriggins!
My friend Rampart! to see you at Bath is fortunate indeed! But why need you doubt the evidence of your eye-sight?

Why, as SOME of my senses have deceived me, I didn't know whether the rest might not be equally fallible; I THOUGHT I saw you alight at the Hotel, but was informed that there was no stranger just arrived but a Mr. Belmont.
O, I can explain this seeming inconsis∣tency!
What, you are just come from Cambridge to stay out a thirty-pound quarterage, and have taken Belmont for a travelling name—being more genteel than that of Jack Spriggins?
No, no, I was going to tell—
Or is it that your modesty shrinks from too much popularity, and you're afraid of being tapped on the shoulder by a FRIEND, whose acquaintance you mayn't so easily SHAKE OFF?

No, faith, 'twas neither pride nor roguery, though, I grant you, they BOTH sometimes assist the creation of new titles.—You recollect my attachment to my cousin Laura?—My father now urges me to marry the old Widow Wheezy, and so sent me to Cam∣bridge to break off my former connection.
Well, but what brings you to Bath?

The sight of my Laura's name in the news∣papers among the ARRIVALS. So I instantly followed her, called myself Belmont, lest my father (who is snug at his shop in the country) might see my name in the papers too, and, by joining us, make it rather too much of a FAMILY PARTY.
And, I suppose, she is sent here to lose the idea of your sweet person—and while you are describing the circles of a ball room, your father thinks you are describing the circles of Euclid.
Even so!
Why it is but TRANSFERRING the seat of science—making the calculations of algebra at a whist table—Studying astronomy, through an opera-glass,— and hydrostatics, at the Pump Room.
Ha, ha, ha! You have not forgot the phrase of a soph yet.

Forgot! Why, I was a whole year at Cam∣bridge, except that part of it that I was RUSTICATED, and so took lodgings in Covent Garden, and attended too, all the philosophical lectures—at Newmarket!— But what is your present plan of operations?

THAT I leave to an abler engineer than myself; no less a man than Pinch, our College hair-dresser, whom I have brought here with me as a tempo∣rary valet. He has been in so many different situations of life, that he can assume any form with the greatest facility.
But what made him give up his College business to follow—
Why you must know, the only school that Pinch is attached to, is the EPICUREAN; and a late Edict, forbidding good eating, went against both his philosophy and his stomach.
Indeed!
Yes, he fell a martyr to his principles, and was turned out for smuggling into College a dinner in disguise.
A dinner in disguise!
Ay, a pig in a portmanteau; a goose in a gown, and a calf's head under a tutor's wig!
Well, these are talents that need not be idle in this region of intrigue.

But you shall judge—I expect him every instant; I have sent him to reconnoitre. He knows the Lady, by having dressed the family at our country races—But I hear him—I'm all impatience. Enter Pinch. Well, have you seen the dear charmer?
O yes, I have seen the dear CHARMER.drily.
But may I hope for an interview?
Whenever you please.
This is an unexpected happiness! But will there be no obstacle to our meeting?
None at all, unless you prevent it yourself.
Nay, then—I'll fly—going.
Lord, you need not be in such violent haste, the person would willingly come to YOU.
The PERSON! Pshaw, you need not be so cautiously secret—This gentleman's an old friend.
Aye, and so is the person I have just seen! Your Father!
My Father! Nay, then all's ruin'd! I thought nothing on earth could ever have dragged him from his counter.
Yes, the mail coach, together with your aunt, Mrs. Malmsey, and the shop porter for a foot∣man.
Why, faith, Jack, here's an enemy in your own quarters.
Unfortunate, indeed! But prithee, dear Charles, devise something for me, the finesse of gallan∣try is quite your FORTE.
Oh, you do me honour—but were I a lit∣tle more acquainted with Mr. Pinch's talents, I could better think in what channel to employ them.
Oh! he'll be sufficiently communicative.
Well, but before you commence hostili∣ties, publish your manifesto. Get a letter written this instant, while we plan the delivery.
Let me see—I have been thinking—Suppose I was to endeavour to carry the letter by introducing my∣self in my own trade—a lady's hair-dresser?
Bravo! that's a hit above your profession.
Oh, Sir, I have belonged to so many trades, that were I to honour the City with taking my Free∣dom, there would be a contest which Company should present with a gold box.
Really!
Oh, yes; my father thought two trades as necessary as two hands; for he himself was a bookseller and a hatter!
What connection could there—
A very clear one—for many of his customers had no head for a book, but they all had a head for a hat.
That indeed—

So my father would fain have bred me both an apothecary and undertaker, that I might have play'd into my own hands—but my mother thought there was a trick in THOSE trades, and so would have me—an attorney.
Conscientiously circumspect indeed!
Yes; but I soon was soon tired of the drud∣gery of the desk, got more creditors than clients, was clapt into jail, and instead of following the law—the law follow'd me.
No uncommon case.

I then went into the physical line; for I had got a smattering of farriery, and produc'd a universal medicine; but after having spent all my time in writing letters of gratitude to myself, and my money, in pro∣curing their insertion in the papers—my medicine would not take.
How so?
Because no one would take my medicine. I then tried ANIMAL MAGNETISM, but that loadstone wou'd draw no money.
No, because its power was not push'd by French impudence; and we had rather be cheated by any one than by our own countrymen—But you were unlucky indeed!
Not much of that—for I then became Ma∣nager of the wooden comedy, and interpreter to the waxwork-court of King Solomon!
Well, here's the letter if you can con∣trive to deliver it, Pinch.

That I'll do, tho' I should be obliged to paper her hair with it. "Miss Laura Stanley." reads Yes, yes, we Gentlemen of the comb are privileg'd per∣sons,
and 'twill have a sure passport under a tete and toupee ions.Exit Pinch.
I wish he may not be too sanguine, Rampart.

But did'nt he say, Laura Stanley? Why faith, if I mistake not, she was one of our cotillion— set last night in the rooms, and, egad, if I am right in the Lady, I am equally so in another circumstance—I can inform you of a rival.
A rival!
A most formidable one—a billiard acquain∣taintance, whom I expect to call on me at the Hotel here—No less a man than Sir Toby Twaddle!
Oh, I have heard of his name, he was knighted when he was partner with Alderman Giblet, the great poulterer, in Bear-binder Lane.
The same, and a most laughable specimen of ridiculous poverty; you'd enjoy—
Pardon me, heaven forbid I should ever be capable of adding insult to the agony of distress.
And I think it equally unmanly, “to hang ”misfortune out to public scorn, 'tis a hackney'd, but true observation, that we are not ridiculous for what we ARE, for but what we AFFECT to be.
Well, I allow—

This, then, is the exact character of Sir Toby, he has a decent annuity, and sacrifices the com∣forts of life, to ape the superfluities; and will dine on two penn'orth of beef ala-mode, at noon, that he may figure away in the side boxes at night.
That indeed!

His dress is the very epitome of his man∣ners, shabbily genteel. He wears point ruffles, and a black stock, to hide dirty linen—his stockings WERE WHITE SILK, till eternal washing gave them the YEL∣LOW JAUNDICE, and by the constant oeconomy of coaxing, half of them has gradually sunk beneath the HORIZON of his shoe—His cloaths—Twaddle speaks within. but hark! I hear him without.
speakingIf the Duke should call, beg he'll not think it necessary to wait.
Rampart, your servant.
Sir Toby, your most obedient—I beg leave to introduce you to my friend Belmont—you're come to take your revenge at billiards.

Oh, positively no, I am so excessively ner∣vous this morning, quite deragé—I drank too much champagne last night in the Crescent, with that comical old invalid, Lord Lazarus, Doctor Drench, his phy∣sician, and Count Quiz; my Lord would take no denial, tho' in general I have left off suppers.
Faith, I believe it.Aside.

The Duke you must know has recommen∣ded matrimony to his Lordship, as an alterative, and he wish'd me to forward the prescription, for, says he, Toby (slapping me on the back, at the hazard of dislo∣cating one of his emaciated fingers,) we all know, my dear Knight, what effect your figure has with the Ladies.
Nay, nay, the elegance of your address is not quite so DISINTERESTED. Come, come, I know you are negociating for YOURSELF.
Why, indeed, I believe I MUST marry, if it is only to put an end to the rivalship of the Ladies.
Very considerate, indeed, Sir Toby.
Nay, Sir Toby, I'm told it's no secret, that Laura Stanley is the happy fair.
Well, positively now, there can nothing be done among us people of fashion, but half an hour carries it from the pump room to the parade.
Why, I know the Lady's aunt, Mrs. Malmsey, is determined she shall marry a man of fashion.
Yes, in THAT she is something of a more rational being than the rest of the family, or I should have cut the connection long ago.
Oh!Half aside.
Aside to Sprig.Now, Jack, for your family portraits—but the old gentleman—To Sir Toby.

A muckworm—reads no book, but a book
of accounts, and thinks the greatest effort of human genius, is the multiplication table.
So!Aside.
I understood you had a rival in Mr. Sprig∣gins' son.
Oh, Lord, no, a poor country cub—but I believe a word from me to Sir Peter Palaver, will make him an exciseman.
S'death, this is too much!
Well, but Sir Toby, you'll dine with us here.
I'm immensely chagrin'd, but it's impossible —I am absolutely engag'd to the Duke, and have just answered his card.
Nay, but Sir Toby.
And from thence to a petit souper, and brilliant conversationè, at Sir Voluble Vacant's, with Lady Rachael Rubbish—Doctor Dosey, and Mrs. Sno∣rum.
Why, that's unlucky then—Jack, you'll get off too cheaply winking to Young Spriggins. I have just won a wager, of a rump and a dozen, of Belmont, and wanted some friends to dine at his ex∣pence.
Hey! what! rump and dozen, Belmont? I hate to spoil a party—I'll make my apology to the Duke.
Oh, by no means—you are pre-engaged.
Nay, but I will.
And have just answered the Duke's card.
Why for once—
And the conversationè

No, no, my absence would only throw a gloom on the hilarity of the meeting—and, Rampart, do let us have that hunting pudding I met with when I din'd last year at your mess; faith I shall beg the re∣ceipt for it.
Faith, you should give me a receipt for it, for I remember you nearly eat it all.

Well, well, ha! ha!—I'll go this instant
to the Duke—he is a good natur'd soul, and we people of rank can take liberties with each other.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE. Old Spriggings's Lodgings.
DIV3.STAGE: Discovered—Old Spriggins, Mrs. Malmsey, and Laura, at Breakfast.

SP.P: Nay, nay, Mr. Spriggins, when you come to Bath, you should sink the tradesman in the man of fashion.
No, no, when tradesmen SINK in that way, they generally get over head and ears, till at last they pop up their heads in the Gazette.
But still—
Tradesman and Gentleman, is a mixture that will never wear; it's like one of my silk and wor∣sted stuffs, the one frays out the other.
There now 'tis again—I wish you had been in London for months together, as I have at Sir Thomas Tallowcake's, in Thames-street, you wou'd have known a little more of the beau monde.
with a sneer.Sir Thomas!
Yes, Brother, and no one more ac∣complished To Laura. It was he, my dear, that made a sonnet on Deputy Blubber, treading on my corn at Pewterers Hall.
Why, indeed, Uncle, in matters of indiffe∣rence, it is better to comply with the singularities of others, than particularize our own.
True, and no one, when he is out of Smithfield, could know my Brother Captain Packwax, of the Train Bands, to be a carcase butcher.—
Why, why, I—

And yesterday at dinner, Brother, asking whether beef a-la-daube, was not bubble and squeak—calculating how much the John Dory cost a mouthful—and desiring Lady Fisgig to eat some pigeons, as they would not do to SET by.
What should I have said?

You should have said, would'nt your
Ladyship do me the honour to take a pigeon, they seem quite to go a begging.
And so I might, indeed, for they were de∣vilishly poor!

And then, I tremble for you at the rooms, after last night's fracas—I am glad Sir Toby was not there—reaching across the table, and almost squeezing Mrs. Drybones' fingers to atoms, in shaking hands with her, because you got the odd trick against four by honours; didn't you set Lady Waddle's head on fire, by knocking the candle against it with your elbow.

Well, but luckily there was no great dan∣ger, as her head and her hair were only OCCASIONAL visitors; for at the first alarm, she popt her bald head from under it in a moment, and lest the tete to burn my fingers—but, however, I endeavour'd—
Yes, you made up matters with a ven∣geance, by running to her assistance, and in your hurry, clapping on poor Lady Waddle's tete the wrong side before.
Lord, I have been never used to—
And then what's worse, when you were at cards, chinking the money on the table, as if 'twas on your own counter—I HAVE, indeed, broke you of wetting your thumb when you deal.
For the matter of that, Sharp's the word, sure you wou'd not have me like you, who spend half your jointure here in rouge and raffles.
P'shaw, but a man worth forty thou∣sand, should keep up appearances for the sake of his credit.

Credit! I believe no man can have more credit from Leeds to London—but what's the matter, Laura, you sit mum chance—what, thinking of Jack still? He's snug at Cambridge—Deep in Cicere—Tris∣tram Shandy, and other writers of antiquity—But Doc∣tor Humdrum, his Master, says he'll soon take his degree, and be out of his time, and then for the widow Wheezy.
Dear Sir, I have no pretensions.
Nay, nay, Mr. Spriggins, Laura is thinking of no such thing—I expect to day, Sir Toby Twaddle to see your niece, a man of the first fashion —dresses—
Ay, there 'tis now, a man of fashion is like an ancient philosopher, or a modern pedlar; car∣ries all he has on his back.
But, my dear Madam, why this precipita∣tion?
True, let's see his bill of parcels—right, child—you want to know whether his stock is real pro∣perty or—
Indeed, Sir, I meant no such thing.

Right, my dear, I knew you was conformable to me; but come, we must hurry away, for Sir Toby will be here before we have done with the hair-dresser—What can make the fellow stay so long after the hour he was order'd—but he'll be here I sup∣pose in a minute—well, we shall see you at the rooms.

No, no, I am willing to do the business if I can, I expect the rider of Mr. Dennim, my draper, this week; stay, here's somebody coming up stairs—nothing but interruption, I wish there had been a counting house at the lodgings. Oh here is the hair-dresser I suppose that they wait for! Ay, ay, it must be so. seeing him. Oh a pretty puppy of a barber!
Your most devoted.
Hem! your servant friend!cooly.
I came to wait upon my Laura.
Well, well, so I suppose—she has been ex∣pecting you for some time, and was afraid you'd dis∣appoint her.
O Lord! not for the universe! poor girl, she has it!aside and looking at himself.
And she is gone in, on purpose to receive you.
I'll fly this moment, and I flatter myself I shall not be unsuccessful in pleasing the young Lady.
Like enough, like enough! I dare say not.
And should I be so fortunate as to obtain YOUR approbation—
My approbation! Ha! ha! ha! Ay, ay, if you give my niece satisfaction—but young folks know best, I have been no judge of these things, these many years.—
But you are not so old—but you—
Why, lack a day, I wore a wig at five and twenty.
A wig! what then? You are not like Sampson, that your vigour should go with your hair.
Besides the mode's chang'd — formerly a quarter of an hour would do, but now, you'll keep a Lady two hours, I warrant you.
That depends entirely on the person looking at himself. I believe I shall do the business in a few minutes.
Well, if you are so expeditious you'll get a great deal of money.
Oh pardon me! money has not the least weight with me! (no faith, I was never much troubled with the weight of it, aside the Ladies have eyes—
Ay, and heads too, as you find to your ad∣vantage.
True, Sir, I have always been happy enough to find their judgement sanction their inclina∣tion—But I am very constant—I never think it ho∣nourable to have too many irons in the fire at once.
There's a touch of his trade, aside. Well, come, but it's a sign you are so quick, or you couldn't afford to lose all this time—but the Ladies, I know, are impatient.
Oh, pardon me! I am gone this instant —Au revoir sings "Gad a mercy, devil's in me," egad, the whole family are enamoured with my person.

Lack a day now! that these fellows should get fortunes by disfiguring the heads of people of fashion! but they have learnt the art from the French, who have transferr'd their mode of fighting, to frizzing —always to attack the weakest part.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE I. Hotel. Table with Wine, &c.

SP.P: WELL, Jack, have not I equipp'd Pinch in the true style of a London rider?
To a nicety—but since he could get admit∣tance so easy as a hair-dresser, what end can it answer to send him to my father as Mr. Callico.
Why, Pinch sound out that old Mr. Sprig∣gins expects the rider, put has never seen him yet; as this is the first season that Mr. Dennim, the draper, has left off riding for himself.
Yes, but to what purpose shall Mr. Pinch—
Nay, nay, have we not already contriv'd to get your letter safe to Laura.
I acknowledge it.

Tho', egad, it required no little finesse to manage THAT; Pinch was obliged to take out your let∣ter, under pretence of trying the heat of his irons that her eye might catch the direction; and afterwards burn off half one of Mrs. Malmsey's side curls, to di∣vert her attention, while Laura slipp'd an answer into his powder bag.
Hah! faith I am glad to find you so merry, and my spirits are in perfect unison with you.

You are come in good time, Sir Toby— We have been drinking success to Belmont, in gaining
a mistress he is laying siege to.—Apropos! how have you succeeded in your visit to Laura?
Egad! now I think on't, Laura told me she knew you.
agitated.Why, surely she did not dis∣cover—

Not the least partiality for you, I promise you; she said she was only acquainted with YOU thro' her knowledge of Jack Spriggins—and gave me to un∣derstand that I had nothing to fear from EITHER of you.
Ay, how so?Rather alarmed.

Why, she said she had an EQUAL regard for Mr. Belmont and Jack Spriggins—and that she should as soon think of marrying ONE as the OTHER— and, what's more, she said I had her permission to tell you so.
Excellent girl!aside.
But don't let this mortify you! affectedly. It was only a handsome way of indirectly hinting who WAS honour'd with her affections—hey!
A pretty plain hint too.
Yes, and wasn't lost upon the PERSON for whom it was meant.
No, indeed, was it not; but, faith, in regard to myself, Sir Toby, I am so indifferent, that I care not, if I saw her in the arms of Jack Spriggins to∣morrow.

Well, 'tis the best way to put a good face on the matter—Poor Belmont! but I can't believe you have so much sang froid, as to wish such a paltry, pitiful fellow as the vulgar dog, you mentioned, should have her, that's being too vindictive.
You KNOW the young man then, Sir Toby?
Oh, perfectly! but not in the habit of in∣timacy, that you'll do me the justice to imagine.
But the young man I thought might have been a formidable opponent.
Oh, no, poor lad! it wasn't likely he should stand his ground, for, between you and I, he is as great a coward.
Zounds, Sir! in a passion correcting him∣self that is, I—I—I—wonder at his ever entering the lists against you.
But, Sir Toby, the gentleman you men∣tion is an acquaintance of ours, and, I dare say, will take an opportunity of thanking you in person for your good opinion.

Why the young Gentleman, as you are pleased to call him, will probably have me to thank for every quarterage he gets from that old Hottentot his father.—Well, adieu! We have all our engagements— Adieu, Rampart!—Your's, Belmont; but no notice to poor Laura! Wish her in the arms of that horrid dog Spriggins! Oh, you inveterate devil!

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE. Old Spriggins at his Lodgings, and Servant.

SP.P: And, hark'ee me, if Doctor Drench calls again, I'm not at home; when I thought yesterday he was giving me a friendly shake by the hand, adad, he was feeling my pulse that he might pick my pocket.
Yes, Sir.

Consulting a physician may be a good re∣gular road to death; but, egad, they take care to make you pay turnpike for it; and then this continual clash∣ing of bells is enough to distract—Pinch speaks with∣out Stay, see who is on the stairs? Exit Servant. Some fresh interruption, I dare swear.
Mr. Callico, Sir.

DIV3.STAGE: Enter Pinch, as Callico, in a long great coat, saddle bags, &c.

SP.P: Sir, your most obedient—just arrived from town—TRAVEL for Dennim and Co.—shall deposit my saddle bags—slip out of my great coat—and receive the honour of your orders.
Adad! why you talk like Sir Peter Pala∣ver at a general election. But I was not advised that you were to be here so soon.
I wonder how the devil you should! aside— The convenience of business has made me alter my circuit.
Like enough! Why your employment must be very laborious.
It does require talents to parry every preju∣dice, and tickle every temper, for it is not often we meet with the sagacity of Mr. Spriggins.
Ha, ha! pleased But how so?
Why, many tradesmen won't give me an order for a yard of tiffany, or a packet of pins, before they know whether I agree with them in party.
Then you must lose many customers?
Not one—my principles on my journey are like a worsted waistcoat piece, will stretch to any thing; and I am often a Whig, Tory, and Republican, in the space of half a street.
Egad, you imitate some of your betters then; you are as wavering as our Member, Sir Peter Pendulum, who, like a turnstile, by giving way to the strongest, always keeps his place.

Now I talk of waistcoat pieces, takes out his order-book give me leave to set you down for twenty pieces—right Nottingham—take 'em again if not ap∣proved. Thank you, Sir, sets them down—Why, there's your neighbour, Alderman Swillet, came to my inn, gave me a pitiful order for a piece of poplin, and carried away with him my whole profit in punch.— But I have a matter of importance to communicate; you have heard of Alderman Mango the oilman?
What, no smash there, I hope; he was reckoned a very good man!
Oh, very warm, a plumb and a half at least! His son is now at Bath, has seen your niece at the Rooms, who has no objection to HIM, I believe; and knowing your predilection in favour of trade—
Well!

You shall hear his proposal. Young Mungo has large property independent of his father, and he is aware that Miss Laura can't marry without your con∣sent, and that you are allowed the income of her fortune till she is married, or of age.
And what then?
Suppose he should offer (with the Lady's con∣sent too) to take the stuff without the trimming?
Poh, poh! I don't comprehend you.
To take your niece, and give up her for∣tune; come, you are a sensible man, give it a mo∣ment's consideration.

DIV3.STAGE: Pinch takes his order-book and makes memorandums.

SP.P: Hem! let me see! Give up her whole fortune—a most tempting!—Ah! but what becomes of my character? The world will be open-mouthed—No, no, it won't do.—Harkee, Mr. Callico, in a passion I have been struck dumb all this time with the impudence of your proposal.
Dear Sir, I only—
How dare you suppose I shall sell my niece?
Sir, my commission—
in a passionI, whose credit has ever been as strong as everlasting, and character as white as dimity!

Nay, but hear me, let her make a deed of gift of her fortune to young Mr. Spriggins, then you, as his father, will stand clear—the world will suppose it a compromise, a recompence for your son's disap∣pointment.
Hey, what!—that indeed!
And as your son knows nothing of this settle∣ment in his favour, you may make what bargain you please with HIM.
Ha, ha, ha! that's true,—egad, yon are a very sensible man—Mr. Callico, the hint's not a bad one.
To cheat his own son aside. Now, Sir, I have in my pocket the settlement of her fortune on your son, to exchange immediately for your consent for the dis∣posal of her person.
Well, but why need we be so precipitate.
Nay, Sir, we must lose no time—In this mar∣ket of marriage, a young lady of fortune is snapt up like a John a Dory, before you have time to ask the price.

Egad, I believe you're right—tho' I have taken a pretty effectual precaution to keep off the young sparks, by lodging HERE in the VERY house of that most indefatigable of all duns—old Crossgrain, the taylor.
Oh, oh!—ah, you've nick'd it.

Yet, egad, for all that, my sister has just found out, that Laura received a letter by means of a rascally hair-dresser—but I have schem'd it—I shall be too deep for him—harkee me, he has appointed to call here immediately, and I have given orders to my peo∣ple to seize him the very instant he enters the house.
Ah! let you alone for management — but there's such tricking, you can't make too much haste, in disposing of your niece.
Right! for when goods are delivered, as we say, they can't be return'd on our hands.
That's true!
And, besides, JACK had a hankering after Laura, and when she is pack'd off, he will have less ob∣jection to the widow Wheezy; for bating her being old—
Whew! what, does he make that an objection?
And then to be sure she has a little short∣ness of breath.
'Twill be the sooner stopt.
Right—and then they pretend to say her teeth are—
Like park pales, one up, and t'other down— but Lord what then?
Come, I'll sign this moment—but harkee —I know nothing of the matter.
Not an, item.
And I only do it to serve my son—it won't be thought I trick'd the young man.
Quite the reverse, I promise you.
And Mr. Callico, the youngster won't scruple the legality of the fortune being settled on Jack, hey!
Never, I'll engage for it.Gets the deed—going.
And, stay—I may depend on't this deed of gift may be a secret from my son.

You may be assured, no one shall know it but the gentleman that marries your niece.Exit Old Sprig. The old codger is generally pretty sly, and shaves devil∣ish close—but for once; I believe we shall leave him in the suds.Exit.

DIV3.HEAD: SCENE the last.
DIV3.STAGE: A Room at Old Spriggins's Lodgings.

SP.SPEAKER: Sir Toby,
SP.P: Completely duped i'faith, to be arrested here by the old taylor, at the instant of success, and that Laura should lodge in the very house of my creditor—and that I should be such a blockhead as to be talking to him this morning, and take him for old Spriggins all the while—yes, yes, the hair-dresser that frizzes all the family, can't be wrong in his information to me,— it must have been Crossgrain himself, I met here this morning, without knowing it—and now I think of it, he seem'd devilishly confus'd, and sneakingly civil, that I might not fight shy, till he had taken out the writ—and that ever it should have been ill luck, not to be PER∣SONALLY known to one's taylor—But here he comes, I must try civility—
Oh, what have I secur'd you at last, you are aware on what account.
Yes, yes, I don't want to bear the items— the account was, I believe, of pretty long standing.
It was; o, oh! then if I had not or∣dered my people to take this measure—
Faith, I wish your people had never taken this measure of me.Half aside.
with a sneer.I didn't find out this morn∣ing, how extensively useful your talents were to the ladies, that you were skilful in a variety of professions.

Yes, I never spare PROFESSIONS when one has a point to carry—but, egad, if you have discover'd my design here by securing me (as you are pleas'd to call it) you not only oppose my interest, but your own.
How so? the charges I have against you, are—
Conscientiously reasonable, no doubt; but if you wou'd but give me credit—
To not a word you can say, I promise you—I am thoroughly acquainted with the business.
I don't doubt it, then you know your BUSINESS well enough not to expect always a QUICK RETURN.
Not if I let you slip, I am sure.
Nay, then I must tell you, you are deceiv'd; I am absolutely not worth twopence.
Who the devil suppos'd you were, and what then?
What then? why within this half hour, Miss Spriggins who lodges with you in THIS house, would have been Lady Twaddle.
Lady Twaddle would she? Oh! oh! that would have been a precious project.
Immensely so; for the old Hottentot her uncle, I am told, is very rich—do you know him?
hesitating.Why—why—not so well as I ought to do perhaps.
A pitiful paltry plebeian, whose ideas are as narrow as his counter.
Hey! what! zounds! I can hold no lon∣ger.Aside.
And then the old Tabby his sister—I HAD cajol'd HER, such a silly piece of antiquated affection! more disgusting than—
Oh my dear Mrs. Malmsey, I am quite transported— this pleasure is so unexpected.
I believe so, why what the devil—
Hush!
You are the pink of politesse—but I thought you wou'd have been more punctual—
I have been detained on unavoidable bu∣siness.Looking significantly on Old Spriggins.
Yes, and I shall detain you some time longer I fancy.
Ah, I don't wonder; I knew the at∣tractions of Sir Toby Twaddle here.Presenting him.
This, Sir Toby Twaddle! no, no, come, come, you are too severe—tho', egad, puppies ARE as much alike, as if they were cut off the same piece.
Why, I tell you this is Sir Toby Twaddle.
Sir Toby! why zounds your craz'd— this is a barber.
What! lookee friend, if you were not be∣neath my resentment as being a taylor—
A taylor!In a passion.
Yes, and should take you by the nose.
That you never will, for sooner than you should shave me—
Shave! why, Brother, I think it is YOU that are mad.
Brother! is this your Brother, Madam?
To be sure it is, Sir.
Why, what the devil a'n't you a taylor?
And what the plague a'nt you a barber?
Barber! S'death, Sir.
Why, lookee, Sir, if you permit barbers and servants to adopt your DRESS, and fine gentlemen in return, adopt THEIR manners—I only wonder the mistake is not made much oftener.
Oh! now be satisfied who I am; my dear Belmont you—
Belmont! why this is my son Jack Sprig∣gins—tho' I don't know tho', how the devil he came here.
Belmont, young Spriggins! nay, then I'll take my leave.
Not till I have first thank'd you for your interest in getting that country cub made an exciseman.

SP.SPEAKER: Laura
SP.P: to Sir Toby.Nor till I, Sir Toby, have made an apology for my inconstancy, in professing an equal attachment for Mr. Belmont and Jack Spriggins.
Oh, Mr. Callico—what, are you come? Well, is the deed safe?
Indeed it is, Sir, in the hands of that gentle∣man.Pointing to Y. Spriggins.
Harkee, Mr. Callico.
Callico! why, Brother, that's the very hair dresser that brought the letter to Laura.
looking through his glass.And may I perish, if he is not the identical scoundrel that told me you were a taylor.
And bamboozled me too—said, you were a barber.
Well, since young Mango is not the man—
And if you come to that, since another person has not the fingering of her fortune, we had better make the best of it.
Let us, therefore, seek our happiness with∣in the circle of our private attachments, since in this place of folly and dissipation, we have at last found it in a—Family Party.
